div.head: A VIEW Of the Whole CONTROVERSY BETWEEN THE Repre≈øenter and the An≈øwerer.
div.p:
THE Repre≈øenter was loth to part with his An≈øwerer without asking him in civility how he did:
Reply,
p. 1. Now from ≈øo civil a per≈øon, I may, for ought I know, have the courte≈øy of a turn or two, for asking; which if he will allow me, I ≈øhall at la≈øt de≈øire a word or two with him before we part, and that chiefly, in civility to ask him How He does? I would intreat him to go back with me as far as to a Papi≈øt Mi≈ørepre≈øented and Repre≈øented, that we may ≈øee how matters have been carried all along, ≈øince that Book gave occa≈øion to this Controver≈øy. How I ≈øhall ≈øpeed in this Reque≈øt,
An≈øw. to Pap.
Prot. &c. p. 125. is hard to ≈øay, for 'tis a favour that his Second Adver≈øary did not obtain, who fairly led the way, when the Walk was not quite ≈øo long as it is grown ≈øince. But with, or without his Company, this is the way I mu≈øt needs go; and becau≈øe I will not do it, without giving the Repre≈øenter a Rea≈øon, 'tis this: I hope to ≈øatisfy
tho≈øe who will go along with me, That he has but je≈øted all this while; and (to make his words ≈øpeak truth for once) has pa≈ø≈øed over all his Adver≈øaries An≈øwers with a light touch (mo≈øt of them with none at all) and the mo≈øt Artificial way of replying, Reply,
p. 2. with ≈øaying nothing to 'em, as can po≈ø≈øibly be met with.

It was well done of him to tell the Reader in the Title Page of his la≈øt Reply, That it was a Fourth Vindication of a Papi≈øt Mi≈ørepre≈øented, &c. for if he had not ≈øaid ≈øo, really men could not have believed it. There were Thirty ≈øeven double Characters of a Papi≈øt laid down with ≈øolemn order in the fir≈øt Book, to tell the World what he is by us fal≈øly ≈øaid to be, and what he is truly in him≈øelf: And this later Character was fortified with ≈øuch Arguments to ju≈øtify his Faith and Practi≈øe, as could be had. What now is become of all this? What ≈øaies the Fourth Vindication in defence of any one particular Complaint, Repre≈øentation, or Argument? Why not a word that I can find, unle≈øs it be where he barely asks, P. 11. What we think of Praying to Images, and of ≈øome few other things, and of more than he would ≈øpeak of, which ≈øtand charged upon the Character of a Papi≈øt Mi≈ørepre≈øented. He puts the≈øe Que≈øtions ≈øhortly and confidently, as if nothing had been yet ≈øaid to any of them. And his behaviour would almo≈øt per≈øwade a man, that his double Characters were yet to be con≈øidered, and his Rea≈øons yet to be An≈øwered. So one would think indeed by comparing his fir≈øt and la≈øt Books together, without ob≈øerving what has come between them; or, at lea≈øt, that the Cau≈øe is dropt by one Side, or the other: And let him that thinks ≈øo, think ≈øo ≈øtill; for that is the plain Truth of the Ca≈øe, which I ≈øhall make out by an Argument that will do the bu≈øine≈øs to the ≈øatisfaction
of all men but the Repre≈øenter; and that is, That He hath dropt it.

This I ≈øhall do in the Fir≈øt place, if it be but to try whether he will take notice of it in the beginning of this An≈øwer, tho he would not be≈øtow a word upon it,
An≈øw. to Pap.
Prot, P. 125. when he found it at the end of another.

And perhaps, now that the length of this Controver≈øy, together with the windings and turnings of the Repre≈øenter, has made it ≈øomething, unea≈øy to be comprehended; it may not be ungrateful to tho≈øe that have concerned them≈øelves in it, to have ≈øome general pro≈øpect of it, all at once before them; which I ≈øhall make as ≈øhort and as ea≈øy as I can, in going through the ≈øeveral Books that have been written in this Cau≈øe, ≈øince the fir≈øt.

div.head: The Fir≈øt An≈øwer to the Repre≈øenter.
div.p: But this was not all; for whereas the Repre≈øenter, not altogether tru≈øting to his Arts of Repre≈øentation, thought fit ≈øometimes to urge, never fail'd to in≈øinuate, Arguments in favour of his ≈øide of the Que≈øtion; The An≈øwerer, without omitting any ≈øhadow of Rea≈øon offered by the Repre≈øenter, took all his Argumentations, and every pretence from Scripture, into particular examination: I ≈øay, he took them one by one in their place and order, and made it appear, that they were very faulty; as we at lea≈øt thought, and as we may think ≈øtill, for any thing that we have heard to the contrary.

Nay, to give occa≈øion to a more perfect under≈øtanding of the≈øe matters, He took Popery as Repre≈øented by the Repre≈øenter him≈øelf in one Colume, and gave him Our Rea≈øons again≈øt it, in another.

And becau≈øe, to gain the greater opinion of ≈øincerity, the Repre≈øenter had with Anathema's di≈øclaimed ≈øeveral points, which, as he ≈øaid, are imputed to Papi≈øts by Prote≈øtants; the An≈øwerer con≈øidered him here too, very particularly, and ≈øeemed to di≈øcover in≈øincerity in the Repre≈øenter, even where one would be mo≈øt apt to believe him to be in good earne≈øt.

To all which I mu≈øt add, That this was done throughout with that Calmne≈øs and Moderation, that his Adver≈øary did not think fit to di≈ø≈øemble it. So that this Book wanted nothing to make it de≈øerve a fair and full Reply, or at lea≈øt ≈øome honourable ≈øort of Conce≈ø≈øion, That the Subject would not bear it.

For ≈øurely no Method of An≈øwering the Repre≈øenter could be more Compleat, Hone≈øt, and Manly, than this was; nor ≈øerve better to put all tho≈øe, for who≈øe ≈øake Books are written, into a way of judging what Popery indeed is, and whether we have rightly condemned it or no, if they were not already ≈øatisfied in the≈øe things; e≈øpecially becau≈øe all was done with that plainne≈øs and per≈øpicuity, that if the Di≈øcour≈øe was in any particular greatly defective, it could not but be obvious to an Adver≈øary, that was, it ≈øeems, thought a fit Per≈øon by his Superiors, to Repre≈øent Popery to this Kingdom, and to defend it again≈øt this Church.

div.head: The Fir≈øt Reply of the Repre≈øenter.
div.p: TO this An≈øwer the Repre≈øenter publi≈øhed a Reply under the Title of Reflections upon it. Now did he in the≈øe Reflections undertake to ≈øhew from Point to Point, That the An≈øwerer had without cau≈øe corrected either the Mi≈ørepre≈øenting or the Repre≈øenting Side, where he undertook to correct them? Did he, as the An≈øwerer has done before him, take the Que≈øtions in their Order, to examine how they were ≈øtated, and where need was, did he pretend to ≈øtate them better? Nay, Did he bear up fairly to any one point of Repre≈øentation that his Adver≈øary thought fit to alter, and try by the force of his Learning to reduce it to what it was when he left it? No truly, his mind did not ≈øerve him, for ≈øtating of Que≈øtions.
But did he not ≈øtand up in defence of his Anathema's which his An≈øwerer charged, not without giving Rea≈øons for it, with Art and Sophi≈øtry? No, he did not ≈øo much as offer at it.

What then was the bu≈øine≈øs of his Reflections? Did they turn upon our Rea≈øons again≈øt Popery as Repre≈øented by the Repre≈øenter? No ≈øure; Nor was it likely that he ≈øhould be forward to an≈øwer our Arguments, that had no Fancy to defend his own.

What? Did he not betake him≈øelf to make good his own particular Arguments in behalf of Popery, again≈øt his Adver≈øaries An≈øwers? Nothing le≈øs, I a≈ø≈øure you; he did not take care ≈øo much as of one Argument belonging to any one point, but fairly left them all to take their Fortune: Is it not enough for a man to bring Arguments, but he mu≈øt be troubled to defend them? Well; From this time forward, the Repre≈øenters bu≈øine≈øs was not to Di≈øpute, but to Repre≈øent. But was it ≈øo from the beginning? The Repre≈øenter indeed has ever ≈øince ≈øo vehemently di≈øclaimed Di≈øputing, that perhaps he only Repre≈øented at fir≈øt. Let us therefore try that a little.

Were there not three Arguments for Veneration of Images, and for Praying to Saints? Were not Mo≈øes, Job, Stephen, the Romans, the Corinthians, the Ephe≈øians, and almo≈øt every ≈øick Per≈øon that de≈øires the Prayers of the Congregation, engaged one way or other? Did he not argue for Tran≈øub≈øtantiation from our Saviours Words, from the Power of God, from the incompetency of Sen≈øe and Rea≈øon to judg in this, no le≈øs than in ≈øome other ca≈øes? I think this is Di≈øputing. There were three Texts of Scripture to ju≈øtifie the Re≈øtraining of Chri≈øtian people from reading the Scripture. And if they are not vani≈øhed out of the Book, there are about ≈øeven Rea≈øons for Communion in one Kind: The 12th Chapter of the 2d Book of Maccab. was once thought one good Authority for the Doctrine of Purgatoy; and St. Matth. 12.32, another; And a little
pretence of Antiquity there was be≈øide, and three or four more Rea≈øons for it; and in this ≈øtrain the Book went all along: Now this I ≈øay, Tho≈øe Arguments were not made by the An≈øwerer, but they were an≈øwered by him, and ≈øo were all the re≈øt, and now they may go ≈øhift for them≈øelves.

Well, but what went the Reflections upon, all this while? By this time I think a ≈øtranger may gue≈øs the Truth, and that is, that the Reflections were to flutter up and down between the An≈øwer to the Introduction, and the An≈øwer to the Book; and to ≈øettle
no where. And now I ≈øhall give as ≈øhort and faithful an ab≈øtract of them, as I can. In the An≈øwer to the Introduction, the An≈øwerer declared him≈øelf un≈øatisfied with the Repre≈øenters method to clear his Party from Mi≈ørepre≈øentations; and particularly, that he ≈øhould make his own ignorant, childi≈øh, or wilful mi≈øtakes, the Prote≈øtant Repre≈øentations of Popery, as that the Papi≈øts are never permitted to hear Sermons which they are able to under≈øtand, and the like. Now from hence the Repre≈øenter de≈øires leave to a≈ø≈øure his Friends, that the Prote≈øtant Repre≈øentations of Popery are ignorant, Reply,
p. 4. childi≈øh, or wilful mi≈øtakes. One would not have expected ≈øo mean a Cavil, ≈øo ≈øoon after he had promi≈øed mo≈øt material Points;
p. 1. But becau≈øe I find in his Prote≈øting Reply, that he is a≈øhamed to own it, I ≈øhall take no further notice of this, than to tell him, He ought to have been more a≈øhamed to deny it; it being ≈øo manife≈øt, that what the An≈øwerer ≈øaid of ≈øome of his Mi≈ørepre≈øentations, he applied to all that him≈øelf calls Mi≈ørepre≈øentations,
An. p. 10. Rep. p. 3, 4. that his utmo≈øt Art will never be able to di≈øgui≈øe it to any man that will take ≈øo much fruitle≈øs pains, as to compare the places. But to proceed,

1. Whereas the An≈øwerer ju≈øtly expo≈øed him for pretending to draw his Mi≈ørepre≈øentantions exactly according to his own Apprehen≈øions, Pag. 2, 3. when him≈øelf was a Prote≈øtant; he now affirms, that he can ju≈øtifie his Prote≈øtant Characters of Papi≈øts, by Prote≈øtant Books, which he names, and out of one of them [Sutcliffs Survey) he produces ≈øome ≈øharp ≈øayings concerning Popery. Nay, he thinks to defend his Complaints of Mi≈ørepre≈øentation, by tho≈øe very words of the An≈øwerer concerning that Popery which the Repre≈øenter allows.
we can never yield to it without betraying the Truth, renouncing our Sen≈øes and our Rea≈øon, wounding our Con≈øciences, &c.

3. He makes the≈øe Reflections upon the An≈øwerers proceeding in the Book, That he either 1. owns part of the Repre≈øenters Doctrine to be the e≈øtabli≈øhed Belief of the Church of England:
P. 11. Or, 2. Does without
good Rea≈øon deny part of it to be the Doctrine of the Roman Church, appealing from the Definitions of their Councils, and ≈øen≈øe of their Church, either to ≈øome Expre≈ø≈øions found in old Ma≈øs-Books and Rituals, &c. Or to ≈øome external Actions, in ca≈øe of Re≈øpect ≈øhewn to Images and Saints, as Bowing, Kneeling, &c. Or finally, P. 12. to private Authors. P. 13, 14. Upon which follows a grievous Complaint of Mi≈ørepre≈øenting upon the la≈øt account.

4. From hence he goes back to the An≈øwer to the Introduction, where he was charged for ≈øaying, That the Popes Orders are to be obeyed, whether he be infallible or not: P. 15, 16. From whence it follows, That Papi≈øts are bound to Act, when the Pope ≈øhall require it, according to the Depo≈øing Power. He replies, That he gives no more to the Pope, than to Civil Soveraigns, who≈øe Authority is not ≈øo ab≈øolute and unconfined, but to ≈øome of their Decrees, there may be ju≈øt exception.

5. From hence he flings again into the middle of the Book, P. 16. and blames the Answerer for ≈øcouting among≈øt the School-men, till the Que≈øtion about Di≈øpen≈øations to Lye or For≈øwear, was lo≈øt; and that he offered no proof, That the Di≈øpen≈øing Power was to be kept up as a My≈øtery, and not u≈øed, but upon weighty Cau≈øes. Then he leaps into the Chapter of Purgatory, P. 17. and affirms, That St. Perpetua's Vi≈øion is not the Foundation of Purgatory,P. 18. but only u≈øed by him as a Marginal Citation among≈øt many others. Then a Complaint of Mi≈ørepre≈øentation again; and becau≈øe Complaints are not likely to convince us, Let us, ≈øays he, depend upon an Experience;P. 19. Do but give your A≈ø≈øent to tho≈øe Articles of Faith in the very Form and Manner, as I have ≈øtated them in the Character of a Papi≈øt Repre≈øented, and if you
are not admitted into our Communion, I'le confe≈øs that I have abu≈øed the World.
Thus far the Reflections: It is now time to compare Things, and to ≈øee how much of the Cau≈øe is left ≈øtanding.

I pa≈øs it by, that the An≈øwer to the Introduction,
See for this An≈øw. to Pap. Prote≈øt. p. 128. upon which the Repre≈øenter ≈øpent his main Strength, is in many mo≈øt material Points untouch'd by the Reflections: But this is a ≈ømall Matter: For,

1. He has dropt the defence of his Double Characters, his Repre≈øentations and Mi≈ørepre≈øentations. For in≈øtead of going on with his Adver≈øary in tho≈øe Thirty Seven Points, with which him≈øelf led the way, he does nothing but nibble about Three or Four of them, and that without taking notice of the tenth part of what was ≈øaid by his Adver≈øary to fix the true ≈øtate of the Controver≈øie even about them: He has indeed thrown about four Loo≈øe, General Exceptions among≈øt the Thirty Seven Chapters in which the An≈øwerer Repre≈øented the ≈øeveral Doctrines and Practi≈øes of the Church of Rome; but he has not with any one of the≈øe Exceptions come up fairly to what the An≈øwerer has ≈øaid upon any one particular Point; And therefore I add,

2. That for any thing our Repre≈øenter has done to ≈øhew the contrary, the An≈øwerer has truly Repre≈øented the Doctrines and Practices of the Church of Rome. And then we have great Encouragement to turn Papi≈øts, ≈øince the Repre≈øenter tells us, That if the An≈øwerer has truly Repre≈øented the Doctrines of the Church of Rome; He, the Repre≈øenter, would as ≈øoon be a Turk as a Papi≈øt.

3. He has ab≈øolutely dropt the defence of all his own Arguments, not ≈øo much as pretending to ≈øhew where the An≈øwers went upon a wrong State of the Que≈øtion; no, nor trying to reinforce his Arguments, where the State of the Controver≈øie was agreed upon on both ≈øides: So that for ought I can ≈øee, the Repre≈øenter fell ≈øick of his Thirty Seven Chapters all at once, both as to matter of Repre≈øentation and Di≈øpute: And this I think was pretty well for the Fir≈øt Reply.

div.head: The Second An≈øwer to the Repre≈øenter, being a Reply to His Reflections.
div.p: BUT we are to thank the Reflections for one good Thing, and that is for the An≈øwer which they drew from another Learned Hand, under the Title of a Papi≈øt not Mi≈ørepre≈øented by Prote≈øtants: In which I ≈øhall make bold to leave out ≈øeveral Material Points, which the An≈øwerer offered too Con≈øideration, and take notice of no more, than what I think may ≈øerve to ≈øhew with what Sincerity on the One Side, and In≈øincerity on the Other, this Controver≈øie has been managed. Wherefore,

1. Whereas the Repre≈øenter cho≈øe to ju≈øtify his complaints of Mi≈ørepre≈øentation, not by taking the fir≈øt An≈øwerers Repre≈øentations into examination, but by referring us to other Books, and to Sutcliff's ≈øharp cen≈øures of Popery; The ≈øecond An≈øwerer con≈øider'd that the Repre≈øenter called the Cen≈øures which Prote≈øtants
puts upon the Avowed Doctrines and Practices of the Church of Rome, Mi≈ørepre≈øentations: which was in the fir≈øt Book di≈øcernible enough, and ≈øpoken of in the An≈øwer to it; but was ≈øo gro≈øly owned in his ≈øecond Book, that no man could now doubt of it: For he made his An≈øwerer guilty of Mi≈ørepre≈øentation for ≈øaying, That we cannot yield to that Popery which the Repre≈øenter him≈øelf allows, without betraying the Truth, &c.A Papi≈øt not Mi≈ørepr. p. 4. This An≈øwer therefore blames him for putting into the Prote≈øtant Repre≈øentations of Popery, tho≈øe faults which we find, and tho≈øe ill con≈øequences which we charge upon Popery, as if we would make the World believe, that Papi≈øts think as ill of what them≈øelves profe≈øs and practice, P. 5. as we do: And much more for putting the≈øe con≈øequences, as owned by Papi≈øts, in the Front of the Prote≈øtant Characters of them, as if we pretended, they were the Fir≈øt Principles of Popery. As for the Doctrines and Practi≈øes of the Roman Church, which we charge them with, the Repre≈øenter generally owned them; but he di≈øowned, as he ea≈øily might, the belief of tho≈øe Con≈øequences and Interpretations which we charge upon them. And therefore his putting them into the Prote≈øtant Characters of a Papi≈øt, was his own Artifice of laying the fouler colours upon Popery on the one ≈øide, that it might look the fairer, when he took them off, on the other. Now to prevent the≈øe Deceits for the future, this An≈øwer goes through the Thirty ≈øeven Articles again,P. 6. to p. 40. to ≈øhew under each Head, what we charge upon them as their Doctrines and Practi≈øes; which is properly matter of Repre≈øentation: And likewi≈øe, what we charge upon ≈øuch Doctrines and
Practi≈øes, which is properly matter of Di≈øpute: By the confounding of which two things, the Repre≈øenter had made a colour for his unju≈øt complaints of Mi≈ørepre≈øentation.

2. Whereas he pretended that he never delivered his own private ≈øense and opinion in Repre≈øenting a Papist; P. 44, 45. the An≈øwerer replies, that he certainly does ≈øo, when he determines concerning Que≈øtions which are di≈øputed among them≈øelves, whether they be Articles of Faith, or not; and that the Catechi≈øm may be interpreted by a private ≈øpirit as well as the Council. div.head: The Third An≈øwer to the Repre≈øenter, being An An≈øwer to a Papi≈øt Prote≈øting against Prote≈øtant Popery.
div.p:
To the Repre≈øenter's wonder, That ≈øuch ado ≈øhould be made about his Fir≈øt Book, the An≈øwerer ≈øales,P. 1. That a Mi≈ørepre≈øenter is ≈øo foul a character, that no man can wonder if we think our ≈øelves concerned to wipe it off; which ≈øurely may be done without offence to any, but tho≈øe that meant us, in the general Accu≈øation. To his complaint that the An≈øwerer makes, All that which they call Mi≈ørepre≈øentation, to be in all the material points a Repre≈øentation of the avowed Doctrine and Practice of the Church of Rome, he ≈øaies, That he has done him all the ≈øervice he can in di≈øtingui≈øhing between matters of Fact, wherein

For the re≈øt,P. 3. he ≈øaies, That his Title related only to his own Book; and the Book, to the Character of a Papi≈øt Mi≈ørepre≈øented; and therefore 'tis hard that he mu≈øt be drawn in to an≈øwer for more than he knows, even for all that any Prote≈øtant may have ≈øaid concerning Popery ≈øince the Reformation; and he thinks it ≈øtrange, that the Repre≈øenter, in≈øtead of defending his own Characters, ≈øhould hunt about for new Mi≈ørepre≈øentations for him to An≈øwer.

1. And he ≈øhews,P. 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. That if what was tran≈øcribed out of the fore≈øaid Archbi≈øhop of York's Book, be Mi≈ørepre≈øentation, it is not a Prote≈øtant, but a Popi≈øh Mi≈ørepre≈øentation: For the Archbi≈øhop cites his Authors for what he ≈øaies, tho the Repre≈øenter left them out; And this the An≈øwerer thought good to ≈øhew from point to point: And concludes, That tho every Doctrine found in Popi≈øh Authors, ought not pre≈øently to he accounted an Article of the Romi≈øh Faith; yet a Church ≈øo watchful to purge, expunge, and cen≈øure in all Ca≈øes where her Intere≈øt is concern'd, is Re≈øpon≈øible for tho≈øe Doctrines, which have her Toleration and Licen≈øe, and which any man among them is allowed to Teach, and to Believe. As for Dr. Beard, and Mr. Sutcliff, he ≈øaies,P. 10, 11, 12, 13. div.p:
THE Repre≈øenter finds as little Comfort in Prote≈øting, as Di≈øputing, and ≈øo falls to Accommodate the Difference between the Repre≈øenter and the An≈øwerer; and calls his, Work an Amicable Accommodation. div.p:
THE An≈øwerer has no Rea≈øon to be di≈øplea≈øed, that the Repre≈øenter now grants we do not Mi≈ørepre≈øent the Papi≈øts in a ≈øtrict and proper ≈øen≈øe, P. 4. viz. by Imputing ≈øuch Doctrines to them as they do not own.
